text: [Music]
in today's demonstrations and i'll have
three demonstrations for you and the
idea is that i'm going to show you how
to apply faster insights and get better
business outcomes
so in the first i'll show you how you
can use data exchanges native
integration with aws glue data brew and
we'll do that to reduce the amount of
time it takes you to analyze profile and
transform those data sets
in the second example john and
jonathan's businesses both take
advantage of local location data in
different ways
and like planet fitness check-ins or
assessing real estate locations
so in that theme i want to show you how
you can work with geo locational data on
aws
and finally finishing up i want you to i
want to show you how you can very
quickly load data into amazon's data
warehouse service redshift
first let's take a look at aws data
exchange's native integration with glue
data brew
i've already subscribed to a product
here and if i select my covid19 well
confirmed cases i can see my products
within that i can see my data set and i
can see a series of incremental
revisions
if i select that top provision you can
now see the assets here
and if i select that top csv file you
now get some export actions available to
you and we're able to prepare with aws
glue data brew and that's what we're
going to do today so we'll select that
option
next you'll you're prompted for an
amazon s3 bucket to download that date
and you're prompted to select any
folders
or encryption options
from there we'll select prepare
once that data has been successfully
downloaded to an amazon s3 bucket will
then get the option to view this data in
aws blue data pro and let's do that
this is aws glue data brew and the
service is intended to help you
understand and profile your data
alongside giving you the ability to
conduct simple extraction transformation
and load with point and click type
simplicity
when you load from aws data exchange
you'll see the data set details at the
top of the screen
including information like any
delimiters the format and the data size
at the bottom of the screen you can see
a preview of your data set
and that comes in a couple of different
formats here you can see a grid of the
data
and next you can see a schema exposing
the first five records of data but you
can also see this in text and tree
formats
today we'll be focusing on etl type
tasks so we'll move to the top of the
screen and select create a project with
this data set
first
we'll provide the project with a name
next we get to choose information about
the recipe
and the recipe is this different steps
that may be contained within your etl
process
today we'll create a new recipe
we've already selected our data set but
as you can see you can import new data
sets or use sample files
and next we have some options around
sampling tags and permissions
sampling we're going to leave default
and just sample the first 500 rows of
this data
tags again will leave default
but we will choose a permission to run
with this particular project
there we'll click create project
[Music]
whilst this project loads i'm going to
pause the video and we'll return so i
can show you how to create basic recipes
now that our project's loaded you can
see the first 500 rows of our sample
data and you can see information about
the individual fields such as the field
title
the type the field
and information about the actual data
within the fields such as the total rows
the unique values and the distinct
values and here you can see the
individual distinct values
and their distribution
moving over to different types of fields
you can see dates are represented here
and
in in unique and distinct values and
numbers here you can see the spread the
median and the mean and the mode of this
particular field
looking at the different functions and
filters we can use we can apply filters
for missing values or valid values with
conditions
we can apply column actions such as
renames duplicates and other things
we can format clean and extract and in
terms of cleansing data you have a
number of functions here like the
removal of special characters or
consecutive white space
equally we can add prefixes or suffixes
to our data or replace individual
elements
other things we can do
is fill with custom values particular
missing rows so backfill or identify
duplicates within our data set maybe we
wish to enhance it with these next set
of options we can do things like create
an additional column based on a function
or a flag column we can add functions
and we can begin to work with the data
within individual fields conducting
actions such as nesting or unnesting
pivoting grouping joining or unions
finally we have the ability to use
functions like encoding mapping scaling
and texting to apply these changes we
can select an individual column
and choose an action and here we'll
rename this particular column
continent with a capital letter
we can preview those changes and click
apply
number two
[Music]
once we've applied those changes we can
now see that we have the first step in
our recipe
as we choose more and more
transformations of this data maybe
dropping null fields
to save on storage
you'll now see that we have a developing
transformation process
once we're happy and we have all of the
steps in our transformation we can
choose create job to begin the process
of transforming this data
we'll provide the job with a name
next we'll need to choose an s3 output
location
once we've chosen that location we can
scroll to the bottom
provide the relevant privileges to
conduct this run
and select create job and run
if that's been successful
you'll soon see a job
waiting to run in the jobs section of
aws glue databrick
check the status of that job and once
complete you should now have a
transformed data set
available to you
in your
destination bucket
